Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Learning to help: Trading spectrum ownership for performance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In contrast with most existing dynamic spectrum access (DSA) paradigms which impose a `foe' relationship between primary users (PUs) and secondary users (SUs), this project investigates a new DSA paradigm which encourages PUs and SUs to help each other by trading spectrum ownership for improved overall performance. Specifically, this project designs two different schemes: (1) Give-And-Take (GAT) and (2) Network Coding + Secondary User Relay (NC+SR). The former does not need to change the radio or the protocol stack of PUs, while the latter assumes that PUs and SUs are capable of performing network coding. In GAT, SUs help deliver the traffic of PUs and in return are allowed to access licensed spectrum in a manner disruptive to PUs. The help constitutes the `give' part, and the disruptive spectrum accesses constitute the `take' part. In NC+SR, SUs help relay PU traffic between PUs. When relaying PU packets, SU relay nodes may encode SU packets onto PU packets via network coding, so that SU packets get a `free ride' on PU packets. Both GAT and NC+SR promise the improved performance of PUs as well as SUs. The project studies the issues of protocol design and performance optimization of the two schemes. Results from this project are expected to encourage incumbent licensed users to embrace DSA to further improve the capacity of wireless network. The project sustains a collaborative research team, and involves both graduate and undergraduate students, particularly the underrepresented minority students,
in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the last decades, the unlicensed spectrum bands have become crowded, due to a proliferation of innovations in wireless communications and networking. In contrast, the licensed spectrum is considerably under-utilized. These two observations have motivated the industry and the spectrum authority to promote dynamic spectrum access so that secondary users can dynamically detect and access idle licensed spectrum bands not being used by primary users, to significantly increase spectrum utilization and encourage innovations in wireless communications.

However, the existing dynamic spectrum access paradigm imposes a `foe' relationship between primary users and secondary users, where the spectrum is exclusively used by either primary users or secondary users. In particular, a secondary user may access the spectrum only when primary users cease using the spectrum, and the resurgence of primary user traffic disrupts secondary user traffic. This paradigm does not offer sufficient incentives to primary users for embracing dynamic spectrum access. Furthermore, to comply with stringent dynamic spectrum access policies, secondary users are demanded to behave conservatively to sense and access the spectrum, resulting in actual spectrum utilization significantly lower than what is feasible.

In this project, we have developed novel architectures for dynamic spectrum access capitalizing on the state-of-the-art techniques and foundational theories in communications and networking. The developed architectures offer significant incentives to primary users through substantially increasing the performance of primary users beyond when primary users have exclusive access to spectrum. Furthermore, the developed architectures enable secondary users to simultaneously access spectrum with primary users. This eliminates the disruption to secondary user communications by primary user signals, and significantly improves spectrum utilization. In summary, primary users and secondary users achieve a win-win situation.

In addition to designing novel architectures for dynamic spectrum access networks, we have also developed efficient and effective algorithms, schemes, and protocols for dynamic spectrum access networks to significantly improve performance. This includes the system capacity optimization, fairness-oriented MAC protocols, countermeasure schemes for security attacks, spectrum sensing schemes to achieve fairness for coexisting networks, theoretical delay analysis for packet transmission, and near-optimal rendezvous protocols at the MAC layer. The research results have been published in leading journals and conference proceedings, as well as disseminated through invited talks, presentations, curriculum development, and outreach activities, to reach the public.

The developed algorithms, schemes, and architectures have significantly improved the performance of dynamic spectrum access networks and the efficiency of spectrum sharing between primary users and secondary users. The research of this project will result in potentially significant societal and economical impacts. It can affect the policies on spectrum allocation and management, and shape the way people communicate with each other. It can also enable public safety authorities to dynamically expand spectrum to accommodate the sudden surge of user data in disasters rescue operations.

This project has offered an excellent opportunity for training graduate and undergraduate students, in particular underrepresented minority students, for research, and developing  workforce in the field of communications and networking. The students have been trained to have solid knowledge and research skills in communications and networking. This project has contributed to increase the engineers, in particular the engineers from the underrepresented minority group, in communications and networking.
